doc.field: Metamorphosis of Narcissus (1937) is an oil-on-canvas painting by the Spanish surrealist Salvador Dalí. This painting is from Dalí's Paranoiac-critical period. According to Greek mythology, Narcissus fell in love with his own reflection in a pool. Unable to embrace the watery image, he pined away, and the gods immortalized him as a flower. Dali completed this painting in 1937 on his long awaited return to Paris after having had great success in the United States.

Metamorphosis of Narcissus (1937) is an oil-on-canvas painting by the Spanish surrealist Salvador Dalí. This painting is from Dalí's Paranoiac-critical period. According to Greek mythology, Narcissus fell in love with his own reflection in a pool. Unable to embrace the watery image, he pined away, and the gods immortalized him as a flower. Dali completed this painting in 1937 on his long awaited return to Paris after having had great success in the United States. The painting shows Narcissus sitting in a pool, gazing down. Not far away there is a decaying stone figure which corresponds closely to him but is perceived quite differently; as a hand holding up a bulb or egg from which a Narcissus is growing. The egg has been used as a symbol for sexuality in other paintings by Dali. In the background, a group of naked figures can be seen, while a third Narcissus like figure appears on the horizon. A poem was written by Dalí to accompany the painting. v · d · eSalvador DalíList of worksSelectedpaintings Landscape Near Figueras (1910) • Vilabertran (1913) • Fiesta in Figueres (1914–16) • Port of File:Mona Lisa. jpg This painting-related article is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. v · d · e Review of Salvador Dali, Metamorphosis Of Narcissus Painting Salvador Dali, inspired by Roman poet, Publius Ovidius Naso (43 BC â AD 17/18) (wikipedia)[b b], painted Metamorphosis of Narcissus in 1937. In true surrealistic style, Daliâs painting contemplates the transformation, narcissism; the painting reveals âthe human drama of love, death and the transformation known in psychoanalysis as ânarcissismâ. â (Maurell i Constans, 2005). Coupled with a poem by the same name, Dali encourages the viewer to experience the poem and the painting together âin a state of distracted-fixationâ (Maurell i Constans, 2005). At first glance, the viewerâs eye is drawn to the golden body of Narcissus bent over a pool of water. From a distance, one can see the perfection of his body; moving in closer, however, we see the flaws. Narcissusâ head becomes a cracked walnut. What appears to be a tuft of hair from a distance takes on the appearance of flames from the walnutâs crack on closer inspection. By concentrating on the painting, as Dali suggests, in âdistracted-fixationâ, the form of Narcissus disappears into the landscape of the painting, transforming into the stone-like hand on the right. Taking a closer look at the hand emerging from the banks of the water reveals the cracked egg from which the narcissus flower is bursting forth. On closer examination, the viewer will see that the crack in the egg is also the shadow, or reflection, of the flowerâs shape. The shape of the hand and of the form of Narcissus are identical. This repetition of form confuses the eye at first, the hand actually takes the form of a statue of the man. By focusing on the thumbnail, with itâs crack so similar to the one in the egg, that the form is clarified. Note how Dali repeats the line of reflective demarkation on Narcissusâ form to the hand. Dali carries the reflection of Narcissus, the man through to the form of narcissus, the flower. It would seem that Dali used the egg, or oval, shape as a nod to his inspiration, the poem by Ovid. Additionally, by repeating, or echoing the forms throughout the painting, perhaps Dali is referencing Echoâs unrequited love
The "Metamorphosis of Narcissus" is a painting by the famous painter Dalí.
